text: That we ever should have met
At each other in the park
How quickly pity leads to love
Merely from a glance in the park
I thought I knew what love was
I wish we might have met so much sooner
I thought I knew what love was
I thought I knew how much I could feel
I didn't know what love was
I've never known what love was
It's what I feel with you
The happiness I feel with you
Happening by chance in a park
No one else has ever felt before!
By the sadness that we saw in each other.
Aren't all of them the same?
I thought I knew what love was
I'd only heard what love was
I thought it was no more than a name for yearning
I thought it was what kindness became
I thought where there was love there was shame
I've been transferred to the Fourth Brigade
Oh, Clara, please don't look so sad
You're the one that makes me happy
I love to see you in the light
As if they'd never touched the ground
Your skin so white, so pure, so delicate
Your smell so sweet, your breathe so warm
I will summon you in my mind
I'm painting you indelibly on my mind
All this happiness ended by a word in the dark
Oh my love, oh my darling
So much happiness wasn't meant to last
I never knew what love was
I want you every minute of my life
I always thought I didn't deserve it
I didn't know what love was
I don't know how I'll live when you're gone!
I don't know how I'll live
Imagine that, a soldier who cries
I had to hide my eyes, so the others on the train
That carried me away from you would think I was asleep
My cousin. She is in such poor health, it's a continual worry
She stays in her room most days, reading
I can't find enough books for her
I also love to read. I've brought a few of my favorite ones, I'd be most happy to lend them to Signora Fosca, though I can't promise they will appeal to her
Captain, my cousin's been driven to reading military handbooks. I've no doubt she will welcome anything in print
You must not be ashamed of your tears
I love you for your tears
Your absence only makes my love grow stronger
And when I cannot bear it any longer
Don't be alarmed, it's my cousin. I'm so accustomed to her outbursts that I forget how unsettling they are to a newcomer
My days are spent in maneuvers
My evenings in discussing the day
"My nights are spent in thinking of you"
Yesterday I walked through the park
To the knoll where we met
Afterwards I sat on the bench
Where we sat all that sultry afternoon
I thought about our room, our little room
And where we shall be happy again
I see us in our room, our little room
And I don't feel so alone any more
I close my eyes, imagining that you are there
The bed, the secrecy, the world outside
I hope I didn't startle you
Not at all. Signora Ricci, I'm Captain Bachetti–
I know. My cousin has told me all about you
I came to thank you for the books
I would have sooner, but I've been so ill
Well, now you seem to be feeling more normal
Normal? I hardly think so. Sickness is normal to me as health is to you
Excuse me. I shouldn't speak of my troubles. I've been going through a period of deep melancholy
I so enjoyed the novel by Rousseau
Oh, it's wonderful. My favorite, really
The character of Julie is a great mystery
You should have kept the book longer to meditate over
I do not read to think
I do not read to learn
I do not read to search for truth
I know the truth, the truth is hardly what I need
I read about the joys the world
No, captain, I have no illusions
I recognize the limits of my dreams
I know how painful dreams can be
Unless you know they're merely dreams
Which offers nectar at the top
The butterfly that stays too long and drinks too deep
I do not read to swim
I do not dwell on dreams
I know how soon a dream becomes an expectation
I do not hope for what I cannot have!
I do not cling to things I cannot keep!
The more you cling to things, the more you love them
The more the pain you suffer when they're taken from you
Ah, but if you have no expectations, Captain
You can never have a disappointment
I must be mad to chatter on about myself like this to you, forgive me
But truly, there is nothing to forgive–
The streets, the fields, the river even
Though there are some lovely gardens
You do like gardens, I hope?
Good, I can show you gardens
And then of course there is the castle
I find it lovely. Probably because it's ruined, I suppose
I didn't know there was a castle
I like to take excursions there
That would be delightful. I don't believe I've seen a flower or a garden since the day I arrived
Of course there is the castle
Ah, look at how they've let this garden go
Captain Bachetti, would you lend my cousin your arm? I wish to have a word with the Doctor
I know how to walk. My cousin treats me like a child
All the while as we strolled, Clara-
I hope I didn't frighten you the other day
I could see you reading my letter
All the while as we strolled -
I'm not afraid of death. I rather think I'd welcome dying. It's being shut up in a coffin, covered by the earth, that I dread
All I saw, all I knew
All that I could think of was you
All that I could think of was you
Reminded me how much I long to be with you
How long I've been without you near
And then to hear a woman's voice
These thoughts are bad for you. Surely if you are sick, you must realize that there is also the hope that you will get better
Hope in my case is in short supply
That's warm from being in the sun
That mingles with a woman's own perfume
There is no absolute happiness in anyone's life, Signora
The only happiness we can be certain of is love
I'm speaking of a superior love
And all that I could do
Love that fills every waking moment
Love that grows every single day
Love that thinks everything is pure
Love that fuses two into one
Where we think the same thoughts
Love that shuts away the world
Love that shuts away the world
A great blindness, if you will
You can be incredibly cruel, Captain
To speak to me of love
Oh, forgive me! I didn't mean to-
The others - well, they're all alike
I've watched you from my window
I saw you on the day that you arrived
Perhaps it was the way you walked
The way you spoke to your men
I saw that you were different then
I saw that you were kind and good
All the time I watched from my room
I would think of coming downstairs
Thinking you'd be repelled by what you saw
They hear drums, we hear music
Be repelled by what you saw
They hear drums; we hear music
What are you doing up and out at this hour?
You know I have a five day leave. I must go
Tomorrow. Go, I want no one to see you here
I am writing to you, Signora
Just as soon as I've arrived
So please consider what I say
My heart belongs to someone else
We're not meant for each other
But since we're forced to be together
Let us try to face the fact
Let us both behave with tact
We must end what never started
As if you'd never been away
Being here with you in the dark
Even more than what I felt before!
When so much time has passed
To dream of you and then
And have some time at last
A month, a week, a day?
I've watched you from my window
I saw you on the day that you arrived
Perhaps it was the way you walked
The way you spoke to your men

I Wish I Could Forget You

text: Did you hear the scream last night?
She knows how to scream, all right
So that wasn't dying, we assume?
No, I think she just fell off her broom
Or they hung a mirror in the room
Just a bit aloof, don't you think?
Never trust a man who doesn't drink
Maybe, though, he just prefers his books
Not as much as he prefers his looks
Which is why he thinks he's got his hooks
Come the summer, he'll be Major
Captain, I cannot thank you enough. Your kindness to my cousin has meant a great deal
You have no reason to thank me
Any attention that is paid to her means so much. Signora Fosca has always had a shortage of friends
My dearest Giorgio. I am writing you even though the Doctor has forbidden it. What a joy to have someone to whom I can tell my feelings. To share my past
I was a young man when my parents died, and Fosca's mother and father welcomed me into their house whenever I was on leave
A girl as beautiful as you are has to
And then she (I) reached the age
As long as you're a man
You either are a daughter or a wife
Or you're a daughter all your life
I'd met this nice young man
I'd seen this nice young man
He tipped his hat to me
I must admit that I was flattered
This is my Aunt Teresa and my Uncle Bruno
From where, if I may ask?
I'd like you to meet a new friend, Count Ludovic!
He was even more handsome up close
I was amazed to see the count take such an interest in my cousin
If I had known you were here, Signorina-
"If he had known," of course he knew
I would have brought you many flowers
I've seen you at your window
I've watched you every day since I arrived
The way you gaze at the sky
For love had made me blind
How could I be so blind?
Or what I took for love
Within a month, he had asked for her hand
I sensed in him a danger
I must admit, to some degree
Once they were married, once he'd received my uncle's sizable dowry, he traveled a great deal, was unavailable to Fosca
He gambled away the dowry. I was forced to go to my parents to borrow from what little savings they had left
Then, one day, as she was coming from market...
Excuse me. You're the wife of a Count Ludovic?
The man's a fraud, a fake
The trips he said he had to take abroad
He took them so he could be with me
He calls himself a count, but he's not
He's never had a title in his life!
But he does have a wife
He only wants to bleed you
Until the day he doesn't need you
I warn you he'll abandon you
As he abandoned her and me
And countless others, I've no doubt
I'm telling you, the man was born without a heart
I confronted him with this information, and he made no attempt to deny it
Ah well, at last you know the truth, Signorina
But you, as well, must face the truth
I've no desire to deceive you anymore
But do admit what you ignore:
We made a bargain, did we not?
And we got what we bargained for
You gave me your money, I gave you my looks
And my charm and my arm
I would say that more than balances the books
Why can't a man, if he can?
Besides, the money wasn't even yours
It belonged to those ridiculous old bores
Forgive me, my dear, but though you are no cutie
I fear you are not quite the victim you appear
Well, let us part by mutual consent and be content
And so, good luck and goodbye
Oh, and yes, we haven't paid the rent
I returned home to find my parents impoverished and in poor health
She began to suffer her first convulsions. My aunt and uncle nursed her as best they could
A flower's only purpose is to please
I spent months looking for the man
By then, of course, he'd vanished
To this day, I dream of finding him and realizing my revenge
My father died not long thereafter
How could I be so blind?
It took her many months to leave her bed
It took me months to leave my bed
When her mother died, she had nothing, really. No one
And so, I went to stay with my cousin, who in some way felt responsible for my circumstances
Why could I not admit the truth?
How could I not have seen through the veneer?
"As long as she seems happy, why interfere?"
Or was I just relieved to know
That somebody would want her for a wife?
In war, you know the enemy
All of us blinded by love
You have to pay a consequence
This is the thorn in my side
As long as you're a man
You're what the world will make of you
A woman is a flower whose purpose is to please
Beauty is power, longing, a disease
I stand here staring at the sunrise
Thinking how we've never seen a sunrise
Thinking that the sunrise only means another day
And thinking can our love survive
If I could feel your touch
If only we had more than letters
If we just could hold each other
Now the sunrise then could be
A thing that I could see
I now sit staring at the mirror
You may not believe it but
I swear, as I stare, there it is, plain as day: a grey hair
Which is more than I can bear
Which I'm ripping out right now
And am sending on to you
As a milestone of my age
As a turning of the page
You won't know who I am
My face, a mass of wrinkles
You came a great distance to read her letters

text: I've begun to fear for my soul!
Both of them were soaked to the skin
Still, it would explain Signora's attitude
Why she comes to every meal
And it would explain the Colonel's gratitude
Gentlemen, I think I'll change my wager:
I long to be with you
How long I'd been without you near
And then to hear a woman's voice
Imagine that, a whole forty days
I'll be there to greet the train
That carried you away from me
I'll have the fire lit, the table set
And once we're in our room
Where I'll be able to care for you
Fosca, you have to face the truth. Please. You have to give me up.
For what's left of my life
A week, a month, a day
Where does he get all the luck?
Yes, he's sick of being stuck in the sticks
He's gone because it's getting pretty thick with the Signora!
He'd better get out quick from the Signora!
That's not an easy trick with the Signora!
I am writing to you, my angel
Though not long since you've been gone
Because in truth, as time goes on
I think of nothing else but you
Oh my love, my sweet, you've changed
You're not the man I thought I knew
At times these past few days together
I would wonder whether you were here
When my son is older, when he goes off to school, there is the chance for us to be together. Will you wait for me, Giorgio? I have to know. We both have to know
I thought I knew what love was
I didn't know that love was a complication
We'll take it in our stride
I want you more than anything
We're young and time is nothing
It was yours; you were mine
Love is more; I want more
I thought I knew what love was
I do know that it's not a negotiation
Then what we have is nothing

text: Be calm, strong. I am yours
The time has come to face the truth
The end is near. The time has come for me to surrender life gracefully. These past two days since you have left, since we were together, have been a revelation
Now at last I see what comes from feeling loved
All that pain I nursed inside
All that vain and bitter self-concern
All those tears and all that pride
Why is love so easy to give
But though I want to live
And that I learned from you
I don't know how I let you
But there you are and there you will stay
How could I ever wish you away?
I see now I was blind
Your love will live in me...
